{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3423119,"name":"","username":"ChocolateFreckle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chocolatefreckle/{size}/232350_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-12T19:15:59.706Z","cooked":"

Our team has already created setpoints for our robot arm and is interested in creating a Method dependent on the current arm position. Our Method aims to read the arm’s position and when that reading is equal to our first setpoint: start its motors. Our code is not quite right. We’re wondering if anyone could help. Our Github is linked below.

public void checkSet(){
arm_Spark1.measurement = arm_Spark1.getPosition();
if (arm_Spark1.measurement = setpoint1){
LauncherFeedMotor.set(0.5);
}
}

the first thing i notice is the single equals sign in the if, which is assigning a value, not comparing whoch is i assume what you were intending.

also, it might be better to instead of checking for exact equality, check for error within a small tolerance. its amost impossible to settle to the exact value for most systems

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-09-13T01:44:55.242Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":56,"readers_count":55,"score":11.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":471140,"topic_slug":"trying-to-get-sparkmaxs-to-give-me-the-position-of-my-robots-arm","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/trying-to-get-sparkmaxs-to-give-me-the-position-of-my-robots-arm/471140/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3423257,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-13T02:18:20.018Z","cooked":"

In your code, arm_Spark1 is a CANSparkMax. That class does not have either a getPosition() method as shown in your post or a getAbsolutePosition() method as shown in your code. VSCode must be complaining about that.

You need to create a RelativeEncoder object referencing the encoder built into your motor, assuming the SparkMAX is controlling a NEO or NEO550.

private final RelativeEncoder armEncoder = arm_Spark1.getEncoder();

You can then request the position of the motor’s internal relative encoder with:

armEncoder.getPosition()

Note that the RelativeEncoder class does not have a getAbsolutePosition() method. You would not want to use that in any case, since moving your arm is going to take many turns of the motor shaft and you want to be counting all those turns to calculate the position of your arm, not just the 0-360 deg position of the motor shaft.

If you had an external absolute encoder mounted to your arm pivot axle, you could read that value for direct arm position, but it appears that you are trying to use the motor encoder, which is a reasonable option.
